data.text: Dragonfly vs. Copper Spur Bikepacking Tents

Dragonfly vs. Copper Spur (both 2p, bike specific) Does anyone have first had experience with both of these items, other then price they seem fairly similar. https://www.nemoequipment.com/products/dragonfly-bikepack?_pos=2&_psq=bike&_ss=e&_v=1.0&variant=41077265629357#specs https://www.bigagnes.com/Copper-Spur-HV-UL2-Bikepack-2021
Copper Spur HV UL2 Bikepack

Our 3-season freestanding Copper Spur HV UL Bikepack tent is built for both on- and off-road adventures. Redesigned to be lighter yet larger. Shop now.

bigagnes.com

Big agnes tents were lighter then msr when I was shopping but once I looked at them in person the msr was thicker on the bottom. I’m pretty rough on gear so I got that. Both were quality made and a similar price, I just chose msr because of that one thing.
data.author: Dan Manning

data.text: I have copper spur & I feel like it's been a great experience. My first tent, ready to set up, didn't have any problems in thunderstorms and heavy downpours. And having out on the handle bars is really convenient
data.author: Hugh Bayard

data.text: Used the 2p Big Anges in Colorado this year. Like the room for me and my gear in the tent. Bought a separate tyvek sheet for a footprint. Lower cost ($22) and more durable than the Big Agnes footprint. Liked how it all fastened to my handlebars, short poles make it an easy fit. Zippers require tender use.
data.author: Matt Schrand

data.text: I try to find nearby sticks for the little patio feature but never works out in my favor lol I would suggest getting the footprint with your purchase
data.author: Hugh Bayard

data.text: I have the Copper Spur bikepacking tent (2p, freestanding), and it works really well for me. I can see how it would start to feel cramped to someone larger (I'm 5'2"), but that's a tradeoff for the weight and packed size.
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: I have the Nemo Dragonfly 2p bike model, no regrets (other than price!. I did purchase during an REI 20% off sale and even then the price was high.... and they want more for a basic footprint!). It packs small (fits neatly on my drop bars), goes up easily and has served me well for a few years.
data.author: Jason Burch

data.text: Hey Nathan! I have the copper spur. Fantastic bike pack and backpack tent. My wife and I share it and we are not divorced yet!
data.author: Ben Moeling

data.text: 🫡
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: +1 for the Copper Spur. I didn't know that you could love a tent, but I love this tent.
data.author: Derek Morgan

data.text: On a recent trip, I had the copper spur and a friend had the dragonfly. Really no big differences, both very good tents. I would say to go with whichever one you can get the best deal on.
data.author: Jon Hubbuck

data.text: solid, thanks!
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: I have a Copper Spur and really love it. It won’t survive 80mph wind gusts blowing it into a parking lot though- I had to buy a new rain fly. But the customer service were great to work with!
data.author: Natalie Moreland

data.text: I have a pretty bombproof 4 season for those conditions.
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: I didn’t pay enough attention to the weather forecast and suffered the consequences. I was grateful to the person who rescued the tent and stashed it in an alcove so it wouldn’t keep blowing around- which meant the tent itself just had a few small repairable tears.
data.author: Natalie Moreland

data.text:
My Dragonfly bikepacking 2p tent in a big storm🙂 https://youtu.be/4waZS5hVAjw
Furtuna de august cu grindina, cu vint la rafale de 90-100km/h. Pe Drumul Maramuresului cu bicicleta
youtube.com
data.author: Covaciu Sorin

data.text: It's a sweet tent, but you might want something lighter. Entrances on both sides are great if you want company or bring a companion.
data.author: Michael Warren

data.text: I took the Big Agnes Fly Creek UL to the Sierra Nevadas backpacking and it was great, but I would not want something that delicate for bikepacking. Bikepacking, I'm getting into camp really late when I'm exhausted and nasty, and I really don't have the energy to deal with delicate things. I'd rather carry the slightly heavier tent, but that's just me. I'm 210 lbs, so the extra 1-2 lb tent doesn't register with me.
data.author: Derek Morgan

data.text: so which tent do you use for bike packing that’s not too worried about ounces?
data.author: Jonathan Enriquez

data.text: Just back from two weeks in the Alps with my Copper Spur, plus a dozen nights in the U.K.. I really, really like it. This is the 1p BP version. I looked at the Dragon Fly, but I couldn’t make sense of the cutaway fly sheet, less so for U.K. weather. The CS is just so well thought out and so far stronger than I expected.
data.author: Dale Weatherson

data.text: which alps?
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: European.
data.author: Dale Weatherson

data.text: 🤣😂🤣
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: So far, I’m happy with my cooper spur 2
data.author: Dev Øutdòórs

data.text: Thanks everyone! Seems like people have more experience with the BA then the Nemo. Wondering if that’s just because it’s been around longer. And the Nemo is always always out of stock.
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: here’s a good vid on the Nemo dragonfly bike 2p. I’m in the same boat trying to decide between both.. I already use all Nemo products. Dragonfly advantages: orange headlight pocket, vestibule tub for shoes also door flaps open wide, D zipper doors, higher tub for side rain, stealth black color (don’t want anyone seeing your pretty bike) Cons: weighs more, isn’t new OSMO fabric, in side walls more narrow than Copper Spur. Copper spur advantages: more places for helmet/jacket/sock drying, weighs less, More space inside, light color reflects light, awesome fly latch connection
data.author: Jonathan Enriquez

data.text:
https://youtu.be/th2q-xMWVzo
NEMO Dragonfly 2P Bikepack After +270 Miles of the Colorado Trail
youtube.com
data.author: Jonathan Enriquez

data.text:
also 12” folded poles biggest “bike/moto” feature. Can also look at other tent options and swap poles out for these $32 14” poles Overmont Camping Tent and Tarp Pole Replacement 142in x2 Aluminum Alloy Adjustable https://a.co/d/5gwOsUw
Overmont Camping Tent and Tarp Pole Replacement 142in x2 Aluminum Alloy Adjustable
amazon.com
data.author: Jonathan Enriquez

data.text: I have an older version of the Nemo. Called the Espri 2. It’s heavier and has longer poles, but it works for me. Personally love Nemo and will eventually upgrade to the Dragonfly.
data.author: Jonathan Robert

data.text: awesome, thanks. I have some stuff from both companies, so I’m torn between the two.
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: Thanks.
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: i use the copper spur , very light and quick to put up but be very careful with plastic clips that clip fly to main tent as one of mine broke. DO NOT PURCHASE FROM ABSOLUTE SNOW as they have just completely ignored my emails and refuse to deal with the issue under warranty so i went direct to big agnes who have sent new clips, although i am still waiting on them arriving.
data.author: Scott Cunningham

data.text: I’ve had to have zippers repaired from/by BA, nothing but good things to say about their customer service.
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: cant fault big agnes ,,, just absolute snow that were disgrace and customer service was non existent.
data.author: Scott Cunningham

data.text: I have both. Each have advantages. Both are very similar. I like the landing strip that comes with the dragonfly so I can leave stuff off the ground in the vestibule. But I think the rain fly system is better with the copper spur because it buckles and you can set it up in the rain if you have the proper ground sheet than set up the rest of the tent to stay dry. If I had a gun to my head I’d go Big Agnes.
data.author: Andrew Hampton Livingston

data.text: I also like the stuff sack/harness system better for the Copper Spur.
data.author: Andrew Hampton Livingston

data.text: the Nemo seems to be 1 burly compression sack vs BA straps hold 2 bags that could slide about, but also can separate bags for storage
data.author: Jonathan Enriquez

data.text: awesome, thanks for the comparison!
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: honestly once I separated my Nemo I didn’t know where the tent poles went so I put them in my frame bag separately.
data.author: Andrew Hampton Livingston

data.text: absolutely. You can’t go wrong with either but Big Agnes wins the competition in my opinion.
data.author: Andrew Hampton Livingston

data.text: I have the original bike packing spur 2. It's great. Very roomy inside and anyone who's used it says it's great too. No idea about the dragonfly but it doesn't look as roomy as the big agnes.
data.author: Mark Obsniuk

data.text: on paper size is almost identical, that’s part of the reason I’m asking around.
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: I've got the Big Agnes and feel it is kinda fragile. We had a wind accident which tore some holes in the top sheet of the tent.
data.author: Vincent Nadon

data.text: sucks, sorry to hear that.
data.author: Nathan Charles Rohn

data.text: accidents happen
data.author: Vincent Nadon

data.text: I have the Copper Spur 2P, it's served well and especially like the rainfly vent. My only regret is I didn't get the compatible ground cloth right away before then changed the clips (it helps to keep the tent dry when setting up in the rain) & none of my older version were left. But thats a 'me' issue. Compared to the price of a couple nights in a hotel, a good tent with numerous nights in the wild is an an absolute bargain
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: I have both for sale if you are looking for one..
data.author: Allin Pequit

data.text: $$ for the Nemo?
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: PM'd
data.author: Allin Pequit

data.text: I’m using a tent called a Durston available in 1 or 2 person. Lighter and better in poor weather than both models you are asking about. Duel vestibule, use as fly only or stargaze as tent only. Footprint and poles are additional. Using short 12” section super light carbon poles. Take a look as an option.
data.author: Ian Johnson

data.text: 2p, nice internal height!
data.author: Matti Koukkula

data.text: I have both tents. The Nemo has much better zippers, has 2 vestibules, and the loops to hang clothes are under the rainfly…all in all the Nemo is a much better tent going on 2 bikepacking seasons now.
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: I also have the Nemo Dragonfly, it’s pretty much my “go too” tent for bikepacking. Absolutely love everything about it!
data.author: Greg Sorensen

data.text: I have a different big Agnes tent. I love how super light and easy to set up it is. My only complaint is that you have to be really gentle with it because it's so thin. The only difference between their bikepacking and backpacking tents is that the bike ones have one extra pole section so it can fold up shorter, and some features like a helmet hanger that may or may not be useful.
data.author: Timothy Faust

data.text: I have the Big Agnes TIGER WALL UL 2 BIKEPACKING tent just because I found it on sale, the only difference is the mine is not fully free-standing and save few grams, I love the tent, easy to install, super spacious, lightweight and quality materials, it definitely worth the money.
data.author: Carlos Andrés Vera

data.text: the tiger wall is my favorite.
data.author: Andrew Hampton Livingston

data.text: Copper Spur UL2; I highly recommend it. Easy to set up, tough, lots of well thought out amenities, packs beautifully on bike.
data.author: Michael Kinkade
